eshmun.expression.operators

Class AndOperator

  • java.lang.Object
    • eshmun.expression.AbstractExpression
      • eshmun.expression.operators.AndOperator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Visitable

    public class AndOperator
extends AbstractExpression
    This class represents an And Operator.

    The and operator can have many children. e.g.: X and Y and Z and ....

    Invariant: it is guaranteed that no direct child of any AndOperator is an AndOperator.

    Notice that And is commutative.

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Kinan Dak Al Bab

    • Constructor Detail

      • AndOperator

        public AndOperator()
        Create a new empty AndOperator.

      • AndOperator

        public AndOperator(AbstractExpression... children)
        Create a new AndOperator with the given children.

        if any of the children is an AndOperator its children will be added For example (X and Y) and Z will yield (X and Y and Z). This is to ensure simplicity.

        Invariant: it is guaranteed that no direct child of any AndOperator is an AndOperator.

        Parameters:
        children - the children of the AndOperator.

    • Method Detail

      • and

        public void and(AbstractExpression exp)
        Adds a new clause to the and statement. e.g: (X and Y).and(Z) => X and Y and Z.

        if the child is an AndOperator its children will be added For example Z.and(X and Y) will yield (Z and X and Y). This is to ensure simplicity.

        Invariant: it is guaranteed that no direct child of any AndOperator is an AndOperator.

        Parameters:
        exp - the child to be added.

      • negate

        public AbstractExpression negate()
        Applies DeMorgan's law to get the negation, which is guaranteed to be an OrOperator. Negates this expression, the result is a simplified expression and not always a NotOperater. The exact type and formulation of the returned expression depends on the class implementing this method.
        Specified by:
        negate in class AbstractExpression
        Returns:
        a simplified expression that is the negation of this expression.
        See Also:
        NotOperator

      • simplify

        public AbstractExpression simplify()
        Simplifies this expression and returns the result, this operation doesn't preserve the type of the expression. The exact type and formulation of the returned expression depends on the class implementing this method.
        Specified by:
        simplify in class AbstractExpression
        Returns:
        a simplified equivalent expression, guaranteed to be an AndOperator as well if children count was greater than 1.

      • toCNF

        public AbstractExpression toCNF()
        Converts the current expression to CNF.

        This method is guaranteed to return an equivalent expression. However if the original expression contained CTL Modalities then this method is not guaranteed to return a valid CNF Formula.

        Specified by:
        toCNF in class AbstractExpression
        Returns:
        an expression that is the CNF equivalent of this expression, guaranteed to be an AndOperator.
        See Also:
        Conversion into CNF

      • toNNF

        public AbstractExpression toNNF()
        Converts the current expression to NNF.

        This method is guaranteed to return an equivalent expression.

        Negative Normal Form has the negations adjacent to the variables (inside). Implications and Equivalnces are simplified into ands, ors, and nots.

        As for CTL Modalities, This method will reduce everything down to AX, EX, AU, EU.

        Specified by:
        toNNF in class AbstractExpression
        Returns:
        an equivalent NNF expression.

      • directCompare

        protected boolean directCompare(AbstractExpression exp)
        Equality check, this method is only called if the passed expression has the same type as this.

        The internals of the implementation of this method depends on the implementing class.

        Comparison is not done based on pointers rather than based on semantic meaning. Two Expressions are equal if they consist of the same variables (based on Name), and if these variables are connected in the same way.

        Notice that certain Operators are commutative, this doesn't change the equality of two Expression.

        Specified by:
        directCompare in class AbstractExpression
        Parameters:
        exp - the expression to compare with this.
        Returns:
        true if this and the passed object are semantically equal (as Expressions), false otherwise.

      • clone

        public AndOperator clone()
        Clones this AndOperator.

        Please note that while the array of children is copied, the children themselves are not. Changes in one of the children could affect more than one AndOperator.

        Specified by:
        clone in class AbstractExpression
        Returns:
        a shallow copy of this AndOperator.
